General Z80 Information


View in Full Screen

The Zilog Z80 happens to be a fairly popular processor. It has been used in the Game Boy, the TRS-80, and all TI-8x graphic calculators.

The Zilog Z80 is a CPU created by Zilog, Inc. This 8-bit CPU is based on and fully compatible with the 8080A CPU. The Z80 CPU contains an address bus of 16-bit, which means it can access 2^16 or 65,535 bytes of memory at one time. The speed ranges from 6 MHZ - 20 MHZ. The TI-86 (and all other TI-8x calcs) uses a 6 MHZ CPU. The Z80 includes 208 bits of read/write memory for register use.

Z80 General Assembly Terms and Concepts:

  • Z80 Status Indicators: These are flags that indicate certain information regarding the status of a certain operation.
  • Z80 Instructions:
    • Load and Exchange: These instructions let you move data between CPU registers and other registers, or between CPU registers and external memory.
    • Block Transfer and Search: Allows you to move blocks of memory from one location to another.
    • Arithmetic and Logical: Allows Arithmetic (adding) and Logical (and, or, etc) operations.
    • Rotate and Shift: Allows the bit level rotation of registers or memory locations.
    • Bit Manipulation: Used to test, set, or reset bits in memory, registers, etc
    • Jump, Call, and Return: Modifies the PC (Program Counter) Instruction to jump to a location in memory and continue executing instructions from there.
    • Basic CPU Control: Controls inner CPU functions, allowing for interrupts, etc.
  • Interrupts: Interrupts the Z80 CPU to execute a routine.
    • Non-maskable Interrupt: Interrupts that are accepted by the CPU at all times.
    • Maskable: Interrupts that can be disabled via assembly language.
